nodes.bodyText:
Most of the comments in this method are now invalid. You should update them.

Favor @x.y.z = "value" property encoding style over @x = { "y": { "z": "value" } }
encode non-empty value property like @x.y.z = "value"
encode empty value property like @x.y = {}

I'd also suggest cleaning this up.

Use shorthand for boolean true.  Instead of writing "@deprecated = true",
write "@deprecated".

Also, remove this from the method javadoc.

TODO: Support configuration for preferring collapsed "map" style over expanded "path" style.
Your changes still don't address most of this.
Redundant. Just dm.size() == 1 suffices.
done. Initially thought dm could be null also which is not the case

By adding more test cases that don't apply to the original intent of the test method, this becomes more confusing. I'd suggest making this more generalized of a method which just tests custom property encoding.
However, this brings up another interesting point. This test assumes the ordering of properties, which is currently NOT deterministic. I'd suggest keeping the tests right now limited to only one property per test case, and adding a TODO to be addressed by whoever implements deterministic ordering. In addition, this sort of testing should be done by PdlEncoderTest, which makes testing the encoder much easier. You can avoid defining the schema as a string literal.

I thought of writing it in PdlEncoderTest but then its in a different module, and also uses SchemaToPdlEncoder.
Now, I have added a new test class for TestPdlEncoder in same package.
Regarding the deterministic ordering I have removed the last test for now.
Remove this line and fix the test data accordingly. It is cleaner that way.
done

the !pathParts.empty() check in the else if block is redundant. Just make it else {
Also update the comment in that block, it is no longer only for empty datamap.
done
License

nodes.bodyText: Add javadoc, my personal convention for test javadocs is: Tests for {@link PdlBuilder}.
done
It's fine that each test (for now) has one root-level property, but none of them branch. Thus, these cases don't actually test your changes. You'll need to make this a little more comprehensive.
as discussed this is not possible right now, as ordering is not deterministic.
nit: I'd suggest mapping the test method name directly to the method being tested; testing writeProperties -> testWriteProperties
done
Please use the Rest.li brace style convention (braces on new lines). This goes especially for your data provider, the return value should be expanded neatly.
done
Looks good overall, just fix this to 2020.
